content:
You are a reader assistant. You simplify a passage from a scientific paper to make it more readable by performing an iterative algorithm that focuses on atomic changes.

You are also given two parameters: DC (Desired Complexity) – a desired complexity of the simplified text, and ILT (Information Loss Tolerance) – a threshold for information loss compared to original passage that specifies whether an atomic change should be accepted or not.

The algorithm is as follows:
1. Determine if the text is at desired complexity (DC), if yes, terminate the algorithm, else continue.
2. Identify a section of the text whose complexity is above DC.
3. Propose a simplification of the identified section.
4. Identify information loss and the severity of it – if the severity for any of the information loss questions is higher than information loss tolerance (ILT), reject changes, else update the current state of the passage
5. Adjust the passage to maintain readability and flow of text, then run a new iteration of the algorithm.

When the algorithm terminates, you print the original and simplified passages

The passage:
However, instead of collecting large datasets once again, we collect a number of smaller datasets containing a few hundred frames each and use transfer learning techniques on the CNN trained on UR robots to adapt it to a new robot having different shapes and visual features.

DC: University student
ILT: Medium
Identify the complexity level of the passage

The complexity level of the passage is high. It uses advanced terminology and concepts related to datasets, transfer learning, and CNN (Convolutional Neural Networks), which may be difficult for a university student to fully comprehend.
Is determined complexity higher than DC (University student)? Answer "Yes" or "No"
Yes
Identify a single complicated section of the passage
The section "transfer learning techniques on the CNN trained on UR robots to adapt it to a new robot having different shapes and visual features" is complicated.
Simplify this section
We use transfer learning methods on a CNN (Convolutional Neural Network) that was trained on UR robots to adjust it for a new robot with different shapes and visual details.
Reincorporate the simplified section into the passage

However, instead of collecting large datasets once again, we collect a number of smaller datasets containing a few hundred frames each and use transfer learning methods on a CNN (Convolutional Neural Network) that was trained on UR robots to adjust it for a new robot with different shapes and visual details.
Identify information loss and its severity in the updated passage compared to the original

Information loss occurs in the phrase "transfer learning methods" as it replaces "transfer learning techniques," which could imply a slight change in meaning, though the essence remains the same. 

Additionally, "CNN" is now explained as "Convolutional Neural Network," which is an improvement in clarity rather than a loss.

The severity of information loss is low because the main ideas are still intact, and the simplification enhances understanding without omitting core concepts. Thus, it falls within the acceptable range given the medium ILT.
What is the highest severity level identified? Is it higher than ILT (Medium)? Answer "Yes" or "No"
No
If needed, adjust the passage to maintain readabily and flow of text

However, instead of collecting large datasets once again, we collect a number of smaller datasets containing a few hundred frames each. We then use transfer learning methods on a CNN (Convolutional Neural Network) that was trained on UR robots to adjust it for a new robot with different shapes and visual details.
Identify the complexity level of the passage

The complexity level of the passage is now moderate. It is more accessible to a university student, as it uses clearer language and simpler sentence structure while still retaining key concepts related to datasets and transfer learning.
Is determined complexity higher than DC (University student)? Answer "Yes" or "No"
No
Provide the final version of the simplified passage

However, instead of collecting large datasets once again, we collect a number of smaller datasets containing a few hundred frames each. We then use transfer learning methods on a CNN (Convolutional Neural Network) that was trained on UR robots to adjust it for a new robot with different shapes and visual details.
